awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: The Psychology of Political Risk in Repressive Regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
The US government spends billions per year on democracy and governance assistance in foreign countries. Nevertheless, one in five elections in Africa since 1990 has been afflicted by significant levels of violence, which impedes citizens from freely voting for their preferred candidates. Identifying how and when coercive violence influences voters is critical to effectively reducing its impact on the quality of elections. This study uses the case of Zimbabwe to understand how citizens make decisions about politics when faced with the threat of violence. More generally, it seeks to understand how the emotional impact of the threat of violence affects perceptions of risks and participation in pro-democracy collective action. The results of this study can help improve efforts to monitor elections and encourage participation in democratic politics by US institutions such as the National Democratic Institute, Carter Center, and USAID. Specifically, it implies that efforts to monitor elections should be focused not only on where coercion is most likely to occur but also on where it is most likely to impact behavior. Second, interventions to prevent and mitigate violence should take into account the psychological resilience of voters.

This study combines a historical analysis of the relationship between violence and voting patterns in Zimbabwe, lab-in-the-field experiments that test for the causal effect of emotions on perceptions of political risks, and a field experiment to test whether emotions can be used to mobilize citizen action. The historical analysis uses constituency and individual level data to test whether violence has a bigger impact on the behavior of voters who are more physically and psychologically vulnerable to intimidation. The lab-in-the-field experiment, conducted through a household survey of opposition supporters in Zimbabwe, uses photos of facial expressions and recalled past experiences of emotions to induce anger and fear. It then measures how these induced emotions affect how participants perceive the likelihood that they personally will face repressive violence as well as their willingness to engage in a number of political actions. It induces emotions using both political and apolitical recall-based stimuli to assess the extent to which the context of the emotions matters. Last, the field experiment leverages a unique partnership with an African political party to test whether negative campaign messages are more effective in mobilizing action in riskier political environments.

por.por_cntn:
Many authoritarian regimes use the threat of repression to suppress dissent. Theory from psychology suggests that emotions should affect how citizens perceive and process information about repression risk, and ultimately how they behave. This research incorporates these insights about the role of emotions in information processing and decision-making from psychology to the study of political participation when faced with the threat of repression. 

To empirically test this theory, this research uses a combination of experimental, quasi-experimental, and qualitative methods in the case of Zimbabwe. First, it tests whether the emotion of fear affects how citizens make decisions about dissent using a lab-in-the-field experiment with 671 participants in Zimbabwe. This experiment tests whether fear induced in a random subset of particpants through an emotional memory task causes people to become pessimistic and risk averse, and ultimately to participate less in dissent. The results strongly support the theory: the fear induction causes reductions in dissent of 14-23%, and increases in pessimism and risk aversion. Figure 1 shows the proportion of participants in the study by treatment assignment who took a behavioral action indicating their propensity to dissent.

In other papers, this research also tests whether anger mobilizes dissent using a field experiment carried out over social media in partnership with 949 participants with a Zimbabwean opposition party, and whether repression events have disproportionate effects on the voting behavior of people who are more susceptible to fear. This research is currently being written up as a book manuscript, and the three papers will be submitted for publication as stand-alone articles.

This project adds to the understanding of the conditions in which citizens participate in collective action against an autocratic regime, and how unpopular autocrats can control populations using the threat of repression. It proposes a new mechanism by which emotions affect dissent, compared to previous research. It also rigorously tests whether emotions have a causal effect on behavior and decisions, complementing the primarily quantitative methods of previous studies. It also extends the study of emotions in decision making and judgment to a new context of a low-income, authoritarian setting and finds effects similar to those observed in Western populations.  

The US government alone currently spends billions of dollars per year on democracy and governance assistance in foreign countries. This project has implications for how governments and international institutions use diplomacy and development interventions to promote accountability and democratic participation in non-democratic countries. It implies that efforts to monitor elections should be focused not only on where coercion is most likely to occur but also on where it is most likely to impact behavior. Second, interventions to prevent and mitigate violence should not only provide information to citizens but should also consider how to create conditions in which citizens can make decisions that are in their interest based on that information.
